I.  THE PROPOSAL  
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Chongqing  Urban–Rural  Infrastructure 
Development Demonstration Project.  
 
2.  The  project  is  a  pioneering  urban–rural  infrastructure  development  initiative  of  the 
Chongqing  Municipal  Government  (CMG),  which  demonstrates  its  commitment  to  reduce 
economic and social inequalities between its urban and rural areas. The project will provide new 
and improved rural roads and potable water supply systems to eight poverty-stricken districts 
and  counties  of  the  Chongqing  municipality,  enhancing  economic,  public  health,  and 
environmental conditions for about 377,000 people. The project includes three components: (i) 
construction or rehabilitation of about 362 kilometers (km) of roads through 21 road subprojects; 
(ii) construction and improvement of nine water supply facilities which consist of new water 
treatment plants and pipelines to boost service coverage, quality and reliability and cumulatively 
provide about 72,500 cubic meters (m3) per day of water; and (iii) project implementation 
support and targeted capacity building for the project’s implementing entities in district and 
county-level governments to ensure the effective implementation  and sustainable operation and 
maintenance of the project facilities.1  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Chongqing’s urban–rural reform agenda is a priority of the State Council. The agenda 
calls  for  stimulating  reforms  in  the  less-developed  western  PRC,  formulating  an  equitable 
urban–rural  reform  model  for  national  replication,  and  providing  for  an  ecologically  safer 
environment.  This  urban–rural  transformation  is  vital  to  allow  Chongqing  to  become  an 
important  growth  pole  in  western  PRC,  an  economic  center  of  balanced  urban–rural 
development in the upper reaches of the Yangtze River, and the first city in western PRC to 
build a xiaokang (a moderately prosperous society in all respects). Embracing this challenge, 
the CMG is prioritizing the equitable and balanced development and urbanization of its two 
primary rural areas: the Three Gorges Reservoir catchment area northeast of its urban hub, and 
a poverty-stricken, ethnic minority area to the southeast. At the same time, the CMG recognizes 
the  need  for  basic  urban–rural  infrastructure,  together  with  sustainable  ecological  and 
environmental  protection.  Many  of  Chongqing’s  rural  districts  and  counties  suffer  from 
inadequate infrastructure due partly to their remoteness, difficult terrain, and either a lack of 
water sources or an inability to harness them. Only 75% of Chongqing’s villages are accessible 
by rural roads; and many existing roads are in poor condition, restricting all-weather access. 
The Sichuan earthquake in May 2008 underscored the vital need to improve emergency road 
access  during  natural  calamities.  Chongqing’s  rural  areas  also  suffer  from  acute  water 
shortages and poor water access. In 2008, more than 8 million rural residents had limited 
access to safe, sustainable, potable water supplies, resulting in an increase in waterborne 
diseases. The inadequacy of basic infrastructure, particularly water supply and roads, severely 
constrains rural economic growth in Chongqing. It also threatens human health, compromises 
the environment, and hampers urban–rural development. 
 
                                                 
1  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) provided project preparatory technical assistance. ADB. 2008. Technical 
Assistance  to  the  People's  Republic  of  China  for  Preparing  the  Chongqing  Urban–Rural  Infrastructure 
Development Demonstration Project. Manila (TA 7108-PRC).

2 
4.  The  project  responds  directly  to  these  urban–rural  and  infrastructure  challenges  by 
providing essential road and water supply infrastructure to selected undeveloped rural areas. 
This  will  strengthen  Chongqing’s  urban–rural  links,  support  balanced  and  equitable 
development, and promote environmental protection and climate proofing. It is an innovative 
demonstration model that can be replicated nationally. The project prioritizes the poorer rural 
areas northeast and southeast of Chongqing. These areas suffer from low per capita gross 
domestic product and poor or nonexistent infrastructure. These communities urgently need 
water supply and rural roads, which are intricately linked. The project will demonstrate how to 
address  water  scarcity  and  water  management  while  ensuring  that  selected  areas  are 
accessible by road.2 By providing urban–rural infrastructure, the project supports the CMG’s 
efforts to improve living standards in outlying areas by targeting counties with high incidences of 
poverty and large minority populations. It is consistent with the urban–rural development goals 
of the 11th Five-Year Plan, which promotes equitable urbanization, balanced regional growth, 
and coordinated urban–rural development. The project supports the State Council’s recognition 
of  Chongqing  as  the  first  provincial  pilot  area  for  integrated  and  equitable  urban–rural 
development. It is also in line with the strategic priorities of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
It supports ADB’s Water Policy3 as well as ADB’s objective of making markets work more 
efficiently by providing infrastructure and promoting environmental sustainability. By enhancing 
urban–rural development, the project is consistent with Strategy 20204 and the PRC country 
partnership  strategy,  2008–2010 5  since  it  delivers  efficient  infrastructure,  strengthens 
environmental  management  and  protection,  and  enhances  inclusive  growth  and  balanced 
development.  The  project  also  improves  the  provision  of  municipal  infrastructure  service, 
supports urban–rural integration, and enhances rural town investment potential while protecting 
the environment. In all, the project contributes substantially to the government’s overarching 
goal of promoting an equitable and balanced regional development and urbanization. 
 
5.  The project will demonstrate the following:  
 
(i)  Stronger  water  sector  enterprises.  The  project  will  strengthen  water 
enterprises and promote the integration of urban–rural water supply systems. It 
will  upgrade  the  skills  of  operations  staff,  improves  rural  system  operational 
performance and viability, and reduces operating losses. 
(ii)  Web-based  project  management  and  coordination  mechanism.  The 
mechanism initiated by the Chongqing project management office (PMO) will 
facilitate  information  exchange  and  networking  of  the  executing  agency, 
implementing agencies and units, ADB, and districts and/or counties. 
(iii)  Watershed  management  and  water  quality  monitoring.  The  project  will 
support  watershed  management  and  water  quality  monitoring  to  strengthen 
environmental awareness and protection of watershed areas. It will also support 
parallel CMG environmental protection initiatives, which include a community 
hotline initiative in Fuling District to improve local pollution control compliance.

(iv)  Rural water supply tariff reforms. The project will support tariff reforms by 
(a) making services affordable to the poor through tariffs that are reasonably set 
according  to  local  conditions,  (b)  strengthening  tariff-setting  mechanisms, 
(c) increasing rural tariffs gradually to recover costs, and (d) gradual introduction 
of wastewater tariffs.  
(v)  Urban–rural road management, safety, and maintenance. The project’s road 
components will closely integrate with the CMG’s parallel improvement initiatives 
relating to road traffic and pedestrian safety; increased public transport services; 
and improvements in maintenance systems, tunnel management, and axle load 
inspections. 
(vi)  Climate-proofed designs. The project’s road and water supply components and 
associated  facilities,  such  as  those  for  drainage,  erosion  control,  and  slope 
protection,  will  support  climate  change  adaptation  and  disaster  mitigation 
measures.  Better  road  connectivity  between  villages  and  towns  will  provide 
alternative all-weather routes during natural calamities.  
(vii)  Environmental awareness and sanitation education. A pilot demonstration 
activity grant of $50,0006 will be provided to a women’s federation7 to support 
and expand a health and hygiene program for the benefit of women and children 
in four villages of Yunyang and Youyang counties, including four schools with 
2,300 students.  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The project’s impacts will be an improved urban–rural environment and enhanced public 
health and quality of life for residents of affected poor districts and counties. The project's 
outcome will be better urban–rural roads and water supply infrastructure in the eight districts 
and counties. Impacts and outcomes of the improved road networks will include (i) improved 
urban–rural links and paved road access in rural areas; (ii) better community connectivity and 
accessibility, and inter-township and county transport integration, through enhanced all-weather 
access to economic and social facilities and farm-to-market access; (iii) safer and more efficient 
travel safety, and improved emergency transit during natural calamities. Impacts and outcomes 
from the improved water supply systems will include (i) wider water supply coverage in rural 
communities;  (ii)  improved  water  quantity  and  quality,  and  corresponding  improvements  in 
public  health;  (iii)  higher  productivity  through  a  reduction  in  waterborne  illnesses;  and  (iv) 
opportunities to develop food processing and other economic activities, which were previously 
unsustainable because of the lack of potable piped water and road connectivity. Appendix 1 
presents the design and monitoring framework. 
 
C.  Outputs 
7.  The project will have three outputs: (i) 21 road subcomponents consisting of about 362 
km of new or rehabilitated rural roads serving 31 towns in eight of Chongqing’s poor districts 
(Fuling and Qianjiang) and counties (Chengkou, Fengjie, Wushan, Xiushan, Youyang, and 
Yunyang); (ii) nine water supply subcomponents comprising new water treatment facilities and 
pipelines cumulatively delivering 72,500 m3 per day of water to 10 towns in five poor counties 
(Youyang,  Yunyang,  Fengjie,  Wushan,  and  Chengkou);  and  (iii)  project  management  and 
institutional capacity building of involved agencies to promote the effective implementation and

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
10.  As the executing agency, the CMG will have overall responsibility for the project, and 
has established a project leading group (PLG) at the municipal level to provide policy guidance 
on project implementation.11 The CMG has also established the Chongqing PMO, which will 
serve  as  the  PLG  secretariat;  provide  overall  coordination  and  management  of  project 
implementation; and be the primary liaison portal between the ADB, the Ministry of Finance, the 
National  Development  and  Reform  Commission,  and  municipal  government  agencies.  The 
Chongqing PMO will engage and supervise the technical engineering design institutes, project 
implementation consultants, and external social and environmental monitors involved in the 
project.  The  PLG  consists  of  senior  officials  from  Chongqing  Development  and  Reform 
Commission (DRC), Chongqing Finance Bureau, and other municipal government departments. 
The DRC chief economist will serve as the Chongqing PMO director and will report directly to 
the chair of the PLG. The eight involved district and county governments are the project’s 
implementing agencies, each assuming day-to-day responsibility of component implementation 
in their respective district or county. Each has established a PLG to provide policy guidance and 
a PMO to serve as the PLG secretariat. Each PMO will ensure provision of counterpart funding, 
engage and supervise the environmental and social design institutes, and report on progress. 
Each PMO will have a director,12 supported by representatives from district or county agencies. 
The  implementing  agencies  have  assigned  agencies  or state-owned  enterprises  to  be  the 
project’s  implementing  units,  which  will  establish  project  management  teams  and  assume 
responsibility for the implementation of specific components. The implementation arrangements 
are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in the project administration manual.13

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
12.  The project will directly benefit about 377,000 people in Chongqing,17 of which about 
47,000 (12.4%) are poor. Residents in the eight poor districts and counties will benefit through 
better water quality and quantity, improved health, reduced waterborne diseases, a cleaner 
environment, improved road connectivity and reliability, and enhanced disaster management. 
The project will create jobs and stimulate economic growth within some of Chongqing’s poorest 
and most disadvantaged urban and  rural areas. In the water sector, the project will strengthen 
water  supply  institutions,  support  water  tariff  reforms,  and  provide  the  basis  to  gradually 
introduce  wastewater  tariffs,  while  providing  watershed  management  and  water  quality

and improved roads will provide better all-weather connectivity between villages and towns, and

A.  Technical 
13.  The project’s road and water supply components will be designed to accommodate 
seismic events. Mitigation measures will be designed into cut and fill slopes, transmission and 
distribution  pipelines,  building  foundations  and  structures,  road  pavements,  and  other 
infrastructure. Geologic and geotechnical analysis during detailed design will also ensure that 
pipeline and road alignments follow routes of least seismic risk, an important factor as project 
roads will serve as vital escape and emergency-response corridors during natural calamities, 
such as the 2008 Sichuan earthquake. Other safety design considerations are also to be 
incorporated  into  road  components,  including  enhanced  traffic  markings  and  signage, 
pedestrian lanes, bus stops, protection barriers, and improved safety education and traffic 
safety  management.  The  project’s  local  road  design  improvements  will  be  promoted  and 
replicated by other districts and counties. The majority of the water supply systems are gravity 
fed, with low O&M costs. The project’s road and water supply components with drainage, 
erosion control, and slope protection, will also support climate change adaptation. A detailed 
description of components is in the project administration manual.  
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
14.  The economic analysis19 indicates an economic internal rate of return of 15.7%–19.5% 
for the roads subcomponents and 17.3%–19.7% for the water supply subcomponents. This is 
well above the economic opportunity cost of capital of 12%. Economic costs include (i) capital 
costs, such as land acquisition and resettlement, and environmental mitigation and monitoring 
costs; (ii) project management and institutional strengthening costs; (iii) physical contingencies; 
and (iv) O&M costs. Economic benefits for rural roads include (i) savings in vehicle operating costs, 
(ii) time savings, (iii) accident avoidance costs, (iv) generated traffic benefits, and (v) income gains 
created by year-round road access. Water supply benefits include (i) resource cost savings (user 
cost savings and user time savings), and (ii) beneficiaries' willingness to pay for improved and 
expanded water services. Benefits that are not readily quantifiable, such as better health, higher 
employment, and climate adaptation, have not been included.20  
 
15.  The financial internal rates of return and net present value have been computed for the 
water supply subcomponents (revenue-generating) at November 2009 price levels. They range 
from 3.4% to 6.9%, which exceed the weighted average cost of capital at 3.3%. Water and 
wastewater tariffs account for 1.7%–2.0% of the average household income and 1.6%–2.2% of 
the poor households’ income—considered acceptable given the improved service compared 
with the current unreliable water supply situation. The districts and counties must be able to 
rationalize the need to improve fee collection in relation to improved services. The gradual 
increase in tariffs will allow for (i) cost recovery of O&M costs, (ii) payment of debt service, and 
(iii) the establishment of a reserve fund to meet planned equipment replacement every 5 years. 
The project will demonstrate that sustainability and cost recovery are ensured for town-level 
water supply subcomponents that are properly planned using least-cost options, gravity-fed, and

C.  Governance 
16.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the CMG, PMOs, implementing agencies, and their project implementing units. The specific 
policy requirements and supplementary measures are described in the project administration 
manual.22  
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
17.  The project will reduce poverty by ensuring that targeted poor communities have access 
to  safe  and  reliable  water  supplies  and  upgraded  and  expanded  road  networks.  This  will 
incrementally improve the living conditions of residents and migrants by providing better and 
safer access to jobs and social services. The project’s components will stimulate investment in 
the industry and the services sectors. Up to 80% of construction jobs created by the project may 
be  classified  as  unskilled,  and  many  are  likely  to  be  filled  by  the  unemployed.  Since 
unemployment  is  a  primary  cause  of  poverty  in  the  project  area,  the  poor  will  benefit 
disproportionately from the jobs it creates. About CNY44.7 million in employment benefits will be 
generated; and women, ethnic minorities, and poor people will be prioritized for jobs during 
construction. The project will reduce the incidence of waterborne diseases, cutting medical 
costs by up to CNY10 million per year during 2014–2033. The poverty and social assessment 
indicates that women strongly support and anticipate benefits from both the road and water 
supply components. Gender has been mainstreamed into the project design, which includes a 
range  of  gender-sensitive  measures  such  as  requirements  for  consultation,  training,  and 
monitoring  indicators.  The  implementing  agencies  will  work  with  women’s  federations, 
contractors, and communities to facilitate the participation of women in paid work opportunities 
for  physical  works,  and  to  ensure  that  all  PRC  labor  laws  and  core  labor  standards  are 
respected. The Tujia ethnic minorities living in subcomponent areas are culturally assimilated 
with the Han majority. The project will ensure their participation through the dissemination of 
information. Livelihood restoration measures associated with resettlement are incorporated in 
the resettlement plan and project design.23 The pilot demonstration activity grant under the 
Water  Financing  Partnership  Facility  will  strengthen  community-based  environmental 
awareness through a water and sanitation public education campaign on health, tariffs, and 
hygiene in Yunyang and Youyang counties. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
18.  The project is classified as environment category A. The summary environmental impact 
assessment (EIA) has been circulated to ADB’s Board of Directors and posted on the ADB 
website.  The  summary  EIA  concludes  that  the  project  has  substantial  environmental  and 
socioeconomic benefits, and that its potential environmental impacts can be mitigated through 
                                                 
21  Financial analysis; Financial Management Assessment (Appendix 2). 
22 Project Administration Manual (Appendix 2). 
23  Gender Action Plan; Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy, Poverty and Social Assessment and Social 
Action Plan; Indigenous Peoples Assessment and Measures (Appendix 2).

9 
the implementation of the environmental management plan. The completed EIAs, based on 
extensive public consultations, comply with ADB’s policies and requirements including ADB's 
Environmental  Assessment  Guidelines  (2003).  The  methods  and  standards  applied  in  the 
preparation of EIAs for the project subcomponents are in accordance with the guidelines of the 
Ministry of Environmental Protection (formerly State Environmental Protection Administration), 
and also meet national and municipal laws and regulations.24 Although adverse environmental 
impacts  are  anticipated  during  the  construction  and  operation  of  the  project,  mitigation 
measures and the environmental management plan are expected to mitigate these potential 
impacts. The designs of the road and water supply subcomponents also address a range of 
climate change issues. They do not significantly contribute to greenhouse gases or increase the 
region’s vulnerability to climate change effects, and they promote the integration of adaptation 
measures into roads and water supply infrastructure development at the county level. Local 
environmental protection bureaus will support the implementing agencies in undertaking the 
environmental  management  plans.  Capacity  building  in  environmental  management  will  be 
provided for the executing agency, implementing agencies, implementing units, and district and 
county environmental protection bureaus. The implementing agencies have disclosed relevant 
environment information to the affected people through consultations during 2008–2009, and 
the results and findings were used to modify the EIAs and the project design. 
 
19.  Construction  of  the  project’s  subcomponents  will  necessitate  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement which have been addressed in the preparation of subproject resettlement plans. 
The project will acquire about 163.64 hectares (ha) of land, of which 85.37 ha is classified as 
cultivated land. In addition, 46.30 ha of land, one-third of which is farmland, will be occupied 
temporarily. Land acquisition will affect 4,238 households (17,456 persons). The project will also 
require the demolition of 37,059.20 square meters (m2) of residential houses, affecting 341 
households (1,387 persons). In total, 4,952 households (20,561 persons) will be affected in 
eight districts and counties. Farmers affected by land loss will be compensated or mitigated 
based on local regulations. Compensation for standing crops, auxiliaries, and other assets will 
also be paid directly to the affected persons. Based on PRC regulations, about 1,539 affected 
persons will be given the opportunity to become urban residents. People losing housing in rural 
areas will receive cash compensation at replacement costs, or cash compensation for the 
structure  plus  house  plots.  Economic  rehabilitation  measures  include  (i)  jobs  during  the 
construction and operation of the project; (ii) high-value crop production; (iii) promotion and 
development of new enterprises and self-employed secondary and tertiary businesses; (iv) 
technical training to the affected persons to increase their skills; and (v) special support to 
vulnerable  groups.  The  cost  estimate  for  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  for  the  30 
subcomponents is equivalent to CNY149.8 million in 2009 prices, including contingencies.25

and impacts of the project are expected to outweigh the costs and risks.26

IV.  ASSURANCES 
21.  The government and CMG have assured ADB that the implementation of the project 
shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the project administration manual and loan documents.  
 
22.  The government and the CMG have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the 
project, which are set forth in the loan agreement and project agreement.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
23.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$100,000,000 to the People’s Republic of China for the Chongqing Urban–Rural Infrastructure 
Development Demonstration Project from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be 
determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending 
facility; for a term of 25 years, including a grace period of 5 years; and such other terms and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and project 
agreements presented to the Board.
